sections.title: Single tooth dental implants
sections.body:
Losing a single tooth can affect more than appearance. Over time, gaps can allow neighbouring teeth to move, alter bite forces, and make cleaning more difficult.

A single tooth implant can replace a missing tooth without involving adjacent teeth, making it a sensible option in suitable cases. As with all implant treatment, planning and case selection matter more than speed.
bullets: Replace a missing tooth without involving adjacent teeth
Planning and case selection guide the recommendation
Designed to keep bite stability and cleaning manageable

sections.title: Planning that protects the neighbouring teeth
items: CBCT imaging and digital models to map bone and nerve position
Guided placement designed to avoid pressure on adjacent teeth
Provisional options and close follow-up with the clinical team

sections.title: Alternatives to consider
sections.body:
Depending on your mouth, alternatives may include:
- a bridge (which involves preparing neighbouring teeth)
- a removable partial denture
- monitoring the space for a period before deciding

We’ll explain the pros, cons, and long-term implications of each option.

sections.eyebrow: When a single tooth implant may be appropriate
sections.title: When a single tooth implant may be appropriate
items: A tooth has been lost due to fracture, decay, or trauma
A previously root-treated tooth cannot be saved
You want a fixed option rather than a removable one
Suitability depends on bone levels, gum health, bite forces, and long-term maintenance considerations.

sections.title: What treatment involves
items: Planning the final tooth position before implant placement
Placement of the implant under local anaesthetic
A healing period before the final crown is fitted

sections.title: Digital planning for a seamless single crown
sections.body: CBCT data, guided surgery sleeves, and close lab collaboration keep the implant precisely positioned and the crown shaded to blend naturally.

sections.title: Support while your implant settles
items: Advice on cleaning around the implant without stressing the gum
Diet and activity guidance while healing progresses
Follow-up appointments to monitor integration and bite
Clear discussion of risks like soreness, infection, or implant movement

sections.title: Common questions about replacing one tooth

faqs.question: How long does a single implant take?
faqs.answer: Many cases take several months from placement to final crown, depending on healing and whether a temporary tooth is needed.

faqs.question: Will the implant match my other teeth?
faqs.answer: We photograph and shade-map the neighbouring teeth so the final crown blends in shape, colour, and texture.

faqs.question: Can I have a temporary tooth?
faqs.answer: We can often provide a provisional solution to maintain your smile while the implant integrates.

faqs.question: Does it hurt?
faqs.answer: Placement uses local anaesthetic and gentle techniques; most patients describe pressure rather than pain, with soreness managed afterwards.

faqs.question: How do I care for the implant at home?
faqs.answer: We show you how to brush and use cleaning aids around the implant to keep the gumline healthy.

faqs.question: Am I suitable for an implant?
faqs.answer: We assess bone levels, gum health, and medical history in Shoreham-by-Sea to confirm if an implant is the safest choice.

sections.title: A measured approach
sections.body:
Replacing one tooth well often means doing very little — very carefully.

Our aim is a result that looks natural, functions comfortably, can be cleaned easily, and fits into a long-term maintenance plan.
bullets: A result that can be cleaned easily and fits long-term maintenance
